tutorial.title: Rent Comparison
tutorial.descriptionContent: Build a webpage that compares the average rent in Paris to the average rent in Barcelona

executableContent.instructions:
Let's code a webpage that compares the average rent in two cities, informing the user which one is more expensive.

To make things easier, we've already added some HTML, CSS, and the JavaScript required to interact with the page. In this project, we'll mostly focus on the logic of comparing two values and creating a useful message with that information. As a first step, we'll create a few variables to store the rent values for the cities we want to compare.

The JavaScript that's commented out will be used later in the project. For now, it's commented out to allow our testing system to function properly. Also, for all lessons, you must code the instructed syntax in the blank lines provided above the query selectors to avoid syntax errors.

1. Save the rent values by creating a `const` variable named `currentRent` set to `1200` and a `const` variable named `compRent` set to `940`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Next, we'll use a variable to store the boolean result of the comparison between the two rent values.

1. Create a `const` variable named `isMoreExpensive`.
2. Store the following comparison in the variable: check if `currentRent` is *greater than* `compRent`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Let's create a message to display whether or not our current city is more expensive than our comparison city. We'll do that by joining the `currentCity` variable, a string, and the `isMoreExpensive` variable.

1. Create a variable named `comparisonLabel`.
2. Set it to the following value:
```javascript
currentCity + " is more expensive: " + isMoreExpensive
```
3. Uncomment the first line of the JavaScript that is commented out. We're able to do this because all variables used in this line have now been initialized in our code.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Let's check the value of our label by printing it in the console. 

1. Code a console.log to display `comparisonLabel` in the console.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Let's work on displaying the rent difference.

1. For the rent difference, create a `const` variable named `difference`.
2. Set the new variable to the value of: `currentRent` minus `compRent`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Let's create a message that will display the `difference` we just calculated in the previous step.

1. Create a `const` variable named `differenceLabel`.
2. Set the value of the new variable to: `"Rent difference: €" + difference`
3. Uncomment the final line of the JavaScript that is commented out. We're able to do this because all variables used in this line have now been initialized in our code.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rent Comparison

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, let's check our new label to see its value. 

1. Display the variable `differenceLabel` in the console.

files.name: index.html
